industry_overview.description: The barbershop and salon industry encompasses independent barbers, multi-chair barbershops, hair salons, med spas, nail salons, and beauty service providers. In the US alone, there are ~1.2 million beauty salons and ~180,000 barbershops. The industry is dominated by small, independent operators — most barbershops have 1-5 chairs.
business_model_types: Booth/chair rental — barbers rent a chair and run their own business (increasingly common)
Commission-based — shop owner takes % of each barber's revenue
Owner-operator — one person owns and operates, maybe 1-2 employees
Franchise — chains like Sport Clips, Great Clips (different market, enterprise software)

how_they_buy_software.decision_maker: The barber/salon owner themselves — usually a single person making all business decisions
discovery_methods: Word of mouth from other barbers (by far the #1 method)
Google search when frustrated with current tool
Recommended by barber supply store or distributor
how_they_buy_software.evaluation_process: Extremely fast and informal. Try it for 5 minutes. If it's confusing, delete it. If it works, keep using it. No RFP, no committee, no demo calls. Self-serve or nothing.
how_they_buy_software.budget: $0-50/month typical willingness to pay. Many prefer free tools. Will pay more if it directly makes them money (e.g., reduces no-shows, brings new clients).
switching_triggers: Getting charged hidden fees (especially payment processing %)
Clients complaining about having to download an app
Software went down during peak hours
how_they_buy_software.key_insight: Barbers don't 'buy software' — they adopt tools that other barbers tell them about. The sales process is 100% trust-based and peer-driven. No amount of SEO or content marketing will overcome a lack of social proof from real barbers.

daily_operations.typical_day: Open shop → check bookings → serve walk-ins and scheduled clients → manage payments (cash, card, Venmo/CashApp) → end of day: count tips, track revenue

booking: No-shows are the #1 pain — a missed appointment = lost income for a chair-rental barber
Walk-in vs appointment balance — many shops do both, hard to manage
Clients booking and not showing up, especially new clients
Managing multiple stylists' schedules on one system
payments: Payment processing fees eat into thin margins
Tips management — splitting, tracking, tax reporting
Deposits to reduce no-shows but clients resist pre-paying
marketing: Building a client base when you're new
Competing with the shop down the street

what_good_looks_like.description: The best salon/barber software feels invisible — it just works. It loads fast on a phone, clients can book without friction, payments process instantly, and the barber never has to think about the tech.
examples: Fresha: free, simple, gets out of the way. Massive adoption because barbers tell other barbers 'it's free and it works.'
Booksy: strong in barber niche, good mobile app, clients can discover barbers through the marketplace
Square: trusted, simple hardware + software combo, barbers already know the brand
what_timber_needs_to_match: Instant mobile experience — must work perfectly on phones (barbers don't use desktops)
3-tap booking for clients — any more and they'll abandon
SMS/text reminders for appointments (reduces no-shows by 30-40%)
Simple reporting (how much did I make today/this week/this month)

terms.chair rental: Barber rents a chair/station in someone else's shop
terms.commission: % of revenue shared with shop owner
terms.walk-in: Client who arrives without an appointment
terms.no-show: Client who booked but didn't come — biggest pain point
terms.chair time: Time spent on a client (efficiency metric)
terms.rebook rate: % of clients who schedule their next appointment before leaving

regulatory_context.licensing: Barbers and cosmetologists require state licensing in the US. Each state has a Board of Barber Examiners.
regulatory_context.payment_processing: PCI compliance required for card processing. Many small shops still prefer cash.
regulatory_context.data_privacy: CCPA/GDPR considerations for client data storage

trends: Booth rental model growing rapidly — independent barbers need their own tools, not the shop's system
Mobile-first everything — many barbers manage their entire business from their phone
Instagram as the primary portfolio and marketing channel
Rise of 'barber influencers' — popular barbers with 100K+ followers drive product adoption
AI-powered scheduling and chatbot booking emerging
Gen Z barbers expect modern, app-like UX — won't tolerate clunky legacy tools

critical_assessment_for_timber.summary: Timber is entering one of the most well-served verticals in all of SaaS. The barbershop/salon market has no shortage of booking tools — it has a shortage of trust, distribution, and deep understanding. The founder has identified real pain points (booking friction, poor support) but these alone won't win in a market where Fresha is free and SQUIRE has $160M in funding.
what_could_work: Hyper-local approach — become THE booking tool in one city/region through direct relationships
Barber influencer partnership — get one popular barber to use and advocate for Timber
Chair-rental-first features — build specifically for independent booth renters, not shop owners
Superior mobile experience — if the product is genuinely 10x better on mobile, word will spread
Community building — create value for barbers beyond the software (content, networking, education)
what_won't_work: SEO as primary channel — too slow, too competitive, and the site isn't even indexable
Generic 'we're simpler' positioning — everyone claims this
Trying to serve all beauty verticals at once — dilutes focus and messaging
Pitching VCs with 0 revenue and 0 paying users
Competing on features alone — the incumbents will always have more features
